generalfeedback.text:
The integration takes place over the rectangle shown below.

[[jsxgraph]] (function() { var board = JXG.JSXGraph.initBoard(divid, { boundingbox: [-1, {#ymax#}, {#xmax#}, {#ymin#}], keepaspectratio: true, axis: true, showCopyright: false, showNavigation: false, grid: false }); // Hide ticks but label axes board.defaultAxes.x.setAttribute({ ticks: { drawLabels: false, majorHeight: 0, minorHeight: 0 }, name: 'x', withLabel: true, label: { position: 'rt', offset: [1, -10] } }); board.defaultAxes.y.setAttribute({ ticks: { drawLabels: false, majorHeight: 0, minorHeight: 0 }, name: 'y', withLabel: true, label: { position: 'rt', offset: [-15, 0] } }); // Define rectangle corners dynamically var bl = board.create('point', [0, {#aa#}], {fixed: true, withLabel:false, visible: true, size: 3, face: 'o', fillColor: 'black', strokeColor: 'black'}); var br = board.create('point', [Math.PI, {#aa#}], {fixed: true, withLabel:false, size: 3, face: 'o', fillColor: 'black', strokeColor: 'black'}); var tr = board.create('point', [Math.PI, {#bb#}], {fixed: true, withLabel:false, size: 3, face: 'o', fillColor: 'black', strokeColor: 'black'}); var tl = board.create('point', [0, {#bb#}], {fixed: true, withLabel:false, visible: true, size: 3, face: 'o', fillColor: 'black', strokeColor: 'black'}); var rectangle = board.create('polygon', [bl, br, tr, tl], { name: "Rectangle", withLabel: false, color: 'white' }); // Labels for x = 0 points [bl, tl].forEach((pt) => { board.create('text', [ () => pt.X() + 0.1, () => pt.Y() + 0.1, () => `(${Math.round(pt.X())}, ${Math.round(pt.Y())})` ], { fontSize: 12, fixed: true, highlight: false }); }); // Labels for x = π points [br, tr].forEach((pt) => { board.create('text', [ () => Math.PI + 0.1, () => pt.Y() + 0.1, () => `(π, ${Math.round(pt.Y())})` ], { fontSize: 12, fixed: true, highlight: false }); }); // Edge styling rectangle.borders.forEach(line => { line.setAttribute({strokeColor: 'darkblue'}); }); })(); [[/jsxgraph]]

We have

\(\qquad \displaystyle I = \int_{0}^{\pi } \displaystyle \int_{@aa@}^{@bb@}y \sin ^{@cc@}x \, \mathrm{d}y \mathrm{d}x \)

Computing the inner integral, we get

\(\qquad \displaystyle \text{Inner} = \int_{@aa@}^{@bb@}y \sin ^{@cc@}x \, \mathrm{d}y \)

\(\qquad \displaystyle \qquad \; = \left[\dfrac{y^2}{2} \sin^{@cc@}x \right]_{@aa@}^{@bb@} \)

\(\qquad \displaystyle \qquad \; = \dfrac{@(bb)^2@}{2} \sin^{@cc@}x - \dfrac{@(aa)^2@}{2} \sin^{@cc@}x \)

\(\qquad \displaystyle \qquad \; = {@ (bb)^2/2 * sin(x)^(cc) - (aa)^2/2 * sin(x)^(cc) @} \)

This can then be put into the outer integral to give

\(\qquad \displaystyle I = \int_{0}^{\pi} 0 \, \mathrm{d}x \)

Which, trivially

\(\qquad \quad \displaystyle = 0 \)

as the definite integral of 0 is always 0, no matter the limits.

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

qtest.description: Test case assuming the teacher's input gets full marks.
